text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today we 
are going to continue on with our yellow curry

adventure now last week we made the curry paste 
which is up the core of this curry and we also

covered what yellow curry is in Thai which as a 
reminder is skanky now this week without further

ado let's dive right into the remainder of our 
ingredients four to five bone-in chicken thighs

I like to also trim off any flabby bits of skin 
300 grams potatoes half a medium onion or one

small one one plus three quarters of a cup of 
coconut milk 1 cup of cherry tomatoes one and

a half to two tablespoons of palm sugar chopped 1 
to 2 tablespoons of fish sauce 1 to 2 tablespoons

of tamarind juice so the first thing that we need 
to do is saute the curry paste now you can saute

it in vegetable oil which a lot of people do but 
I'm going to saute it in reduced and separate it

coconut milk and you've seen me do this before 
in massaman and green curry and I'm going to

do it again because it's a traditional way and 
you also get more coconut flavor because you're

adding more sort of concentrated coconut to it 
but it's not a big deal if you just do vegetable

oil so what I'm going to do here is I'm going to 
bring it to a boil at about medium heat so not

so it's not splattering all over the place and 
then once it reduces to very very thick you're

going to start to notice that the texture 
of the coconut milk will be different it'll

start to separate and that's the coconut oil 
in there getting destabilized and separating

itself from the remainder of the coconut milk 
so that's what we're looking for if you're using

canned coconut milk or some other some coconut 
milk that's been processed and homogenized and

stabilized that might not happen not a worry you 
can still saute the curry paste in just reduced

coconut milk it doesn't have to separate 
so we're going to wait till that happens

okay so we're almost there I can start to see the 
separation happening around the edges already if

yours doesn't reduce it down to this point and 
then saute the curry paste in this anyway it'll

be fine and it doesn't have to separate a lot 
a lot because once you add the curry paste and

you keep cooking it Oh it'll keep separating as 
you do that there so I'm going to go in with my

curry paste that we freshly made again the video 
will be in the tutorial section of my website for

the curry paste you can also use store-bought 
that's probably about five tablespoons and then

I'm going to cook this in the reduced coconut 
milk the heat at this point keep it pretty on

the medium side because curry paste can burn 
and why are we bothering with this separation

I mean it's not absolutely necessary but you 
get a much prettier curry in the end they'll

be a beautiful yellow shiny coconut oil that's 
coating the top of your curry making it just

really beautiful really bright colors so that's 
like a a standard presentation of Thai curries

there's a lot of them if it's coconut milk base 
will have that beautiful sheen of oil on top so

it's really just for aesthetics to spend a couple 
minutes and this is the consistency you're looking

for I'm going to toss in our chicken just to get 
it coated smother the chicken in the curry paste

really get in there and this is so satisfying 
I love this part once the chickens all coated

we're going to add the remaining coconut milk and 
then we're also going to add some water and that's

because this coconut milk is what we call a first 
press or the head of the coconut milk it's very

concentrated and it'll make the curry a little 
bit rich unnecessarily rich so we want to add

some water to thin it out if you are making fresh 
coconut milk for this you would take the coconut

pulp press it again with more water and that'll 
be or thin part of the coconut milk or what we

call the tail of the coconut milk then we'll use 
that to make up there the rest of the curry but we

can just use water as well okay so we're going 
to let that come to a simmer but before we do

that we are going to give it some seasonings 
I'm going to add half of our fish sauce just

so the chicken has something to absorb so the the 
meat is not bland we're also going to add half of

our palm sugar and we're going to bring this to a 
simmer and let it cook let it braise for about 30

minutes this is dark meat chicken it's delicious 
when it's cooked slowly until it's fork-tender

okay we're going to let it go for 30 minutes then 
we're going to add all our vegetables so we'll be

right back so while our curry is simmering away 
we're going to talk a little bit about the cherry

tomatoes I'm going to put them in whole but when 
you cook whole cherry tomatoes what I'm going to

do for us is pierce the cherry tomatoes so you 
know just with the tip of a sharp paring knife

until they are broken okay just like that now the 
reason is when you cook whole cherry tomatoes you

either want to cut it in half or cook them until 
they break because what you want to avoid is heat

them up but not quite enough that they break 
and split but it's enough that it's hot and

then someone goes to eat it and it boom explodes 
in their mouth and burn their mouth it's really

not that Pleasant so what I'm going to do is I'm 
going to stir these in at the end because I don't

want these to mush because then it disintegrates 
into the curry and it dilutes the curry and all

that but the residual heat of the curry is just 
sort of going to gently cook the tomatoes most

of them are probably going to split just from 
that residual heat anyway but I don't want to

take any chances so I want to make sure they are 
already broken so the hot steam inside has a way

to get out okay so just something to consider 
whenever you cook with cherry tomatoes so it's

been about 30 minutes now and the chicken should 
almost be fork tender generally thighs take about

45 minutes to get there but this is when we're 
going to add all our vegetables we are going to

add our potatoes so I'm using waxy potato which 
these yellow potatoes you can also use the red

skinned one from using these as opposed to russet 
potatoes which are starchy potatoes because they

hold their shape much better in soup the starchy 
ones which are good for making baked potatoes and

mashed potatoes and whatnot they if you overcook 
them they will tend to sort of disintegrate into

the curry and we don't want that so you want 
something that can hold the shape better because

we want them to cook for quite a while so they 
have a chance to absorb so we don't just want

to you know cook them till they're just right 
and then take it off we want them to sit there

and hang out and mingle with the curry sauce and 
also we're going to add some onions now the onions

if I add them at this point when it's done it'll 
still be in or pieces if you want it to completely

disintegrate and sweet and be sort of become a 
part of the sauce you can add them right at the

beginning so it just depends or if you like 
them still a bit crunchy hold off until the

last few minutes and then add them then so you 
can definitely customize now at this point you

can add a little bit more water if you feel like 
there's not enough liquid there which I'm going

to do because you can never really predict when 
you make something that cooks for a long time how

much water is going to evaporate exactly each 
time now we're going to let this go until the

potatoes are cooked and the onions are nice and 
soft and then we're going to come back and give it

a taste okay so it's been about 15 to 20 minutes 
the potatoes are cooked and they've absorbed all

sorts of flavor in there and so I'm going to turn 
off the heat and then I'm going to just check that

the chicken has become fork tender or knife tender 
in my case it's okay I still sort of have an idea

yep that's tender and now at this point you want 
to taste and adjust your final seasonings remember

we didn't add everything so look at all that 
beautiful coconut oil that has floated to the

top now some of that is also chicken fat that's 
come out if you don't want a lot of added chicken

fat you can trim it off the chicken to begin 
with if you didn't use skin skin on chicken fat

you won't have as much you can also this is too 
much scoop some off at this point give it a taste

quite good so we're going to go I'm going to add 
just a little bit more of the fish sauce maybe

not everything some of the remaining sugar and 
then I'm also going to add some tamarind juice

and tamarind juice I'm adding to this because this 
is a very rich and hearty kind of curry and it's

mainly salty with a little bit of sweet adding 
acid will brighten it up and it'll turn it from

this heavy Hardy flats to into something that's 
ah so much more exciting so just a little bit

you don't want it to taste sour so I'm going in 
with maybe one tablespoon first depending on the

concentration of your tamarind juice and then give 
it a stir taste it again yeah I think we're there

I think we're there I don't want to make it too 
sweet I could add all the sugar but you know what

I'm going to hold that off and at this point we're 
gonna go in with the tomatoes which will also add

a burst of acidity when you eat it you want to 
stir it in right after you turn off the heat and

then the residual heat of the curry will warm it 
through we'll cook it and by the time you serve it

some of them may have actually split open but if 
they don't then we've taken care of that as well

so that's pretty much that now you just serve the 
curry the done here is our beautiful gang curry

yes let's do that oh that looks nice now 
the standard garnish for this is usually

fried shallots crispy fried shallots and it's the 
same one I don't have any with me today because I

forgot admittedly but what you would do is fry 
the shallots the same way I did in my hat yeah

Fried Chicken episode so if you want to be you 
know to go all out in authenticity check out

that episode and I go through how you can make 
crispy delicious fried shallots to sprinkle on

top of this curry so always always always serve 
this curry with rice I've also had this curry

with quinoa and that was really delicious as 
well so let's try a piece of chicken and a lot

of sauce there we go and let's taste it oh I also 
want a little bit of onion mmm soft sweet onions

if you can get a hold of sweet onions rather than 
regular yellow onions do so because that will be

more delicious careful it's hot that's so good 
I want to do a yummy dance in fact I will do a

yummy dance that was really good yes please it's 
it's really easy as you can see now if you want

to use store-bought curry paste and make this a 
quick and easy thing go for it or make lots of

extra curry paste so you'll have extra and keep it 
in the freezer in either case doo-doo-doo try this

one out let me know how it goes either through 
facebook twitter or instagram send me photo or

you can contact me through my website and if you 
like the show please click to subscribe so I can

keep producing these shows for you and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious Thai meal
